manuscript.notes: The ms. was designated first as R1; according to Geldner handwriting and paper of the ms. agree with the date given in the Āšīrwād (for which see also the ms. MRL F97.16 [Dhabhar 1923b, p. 54]). The introductory prayers are supplied by later hand, also NyXwar; since G 1–5 are missing, it seems that the old ms. lost its beginning folios on which were written the smaller prayers, the Gāhs and Ny 1. The quantity of the Yašts in Jm4 exceeds the daily obligation and the quantity of translated Yašts; it seems, as if already in the 14th c. the Parsis started creating XA–Mss. that were not in correlation to the daily prayer obligations.

manuscript.ms_history: For the Yts cf. EMU7. Besides Lb1, O3 is the first XA ms. that became known in Europe. "In the codex it is furthermore noted that Anquetil had seen it and had made mention of it" (Geldner); inside the note: "The Zend of Zeratusht in the ancient Persic character. Fras. P. 35". Anquetil writes: "J'en ai vu un pareil à Oxford, chez le Docteur Hunt. Il a été apporté en Angleterre par M. Frazer, qui l'avoit eu de Bikh, Destour Mobed de Surate. Le même Docteur possede les Néaeschs Zends; le Nékah, en Caracteres Zends, copiés l'an d'Iezdedjerd 1042 (de Jesus Christ 1672*). C'est un des Manuscrits du Docteur Hyde. The codex was ordered by Ērvad Kāmdīn Ērvad Bīharām Ērvad Rāmjī Aklesarā. *Lb1

Sims-Williams gives the information (in http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Royal_MS_16_B_VI): "The same scribe Herbad Hormuzyar also copied the manuscript Ṣad dar (Royal MS 16 B VII) in 1674 for the same patron who is there described as the Agent (Modi) for the English (Angrez)." After Hydes's death it became part of the Royal Collection presented to the British Museum by George II in 1757 as part of the Old Royal Library

manuscript.donator_purchase: Previously in the possession of Frāmjī Faredūnjī Madan (see Prol., p. iii). It came into the possession of Jāmāspjī Minocherjī JāmāspĀsā who inherited one part of his collection to his son Minocher (died 1922); finally it came into the possession of Kaikhusro M. JamaspAsa [Keykhosrō M. JāmāspĀsā], the grandson of Minocher's brother Kaikhusro (see JamaspAsa 1991, pp. IX–X)
manuscript.ms_history: On the relation of F1, E1, Pt1 Geldner, Prol., p. xli writes: "The relation of F1 to E1–Pt1 may now be thus represented in detail. The Nyâishes in E1 are probably copied from F1 but are influenced by the Vulgate; in Pt1 on the contrary they are taken from the Khorda Avestâ copy. Yashts 1–3 in E1 and Pt1 descend from a common original, related to F1 but not identical with it. [Fn. It must be remembered that in E1 the Âfrîngâns stand between the Nyâishes and the Yashts. In the case of the Âfrîngâns, the copyist must at all events have made use of another source for they are not found in F1 at all]. Beginning with Yasht 4, E1 is based throughout upon F1; but in Pt1 the Ms. F1 is the basis only in Yashts 5–8. 10–13. 15. 17–19, [Fn. The last two Yashts are so unimportant that they may practically be left out of account. Also the Srôsh Yasht with Y. 57 complete (Yt. 11a), is copied in Pt1 from F1. YtSrH in F1 is already much influenced by the Vulgate.]". Description in the Catalogue: "Khordeh–Avesta – containing all larger yashts, followed by hom a vanunts yashts and thereafter the nam sitayesn"

manuscript.donator_purchase: Written for Mobed Behzād Bahrām, Surat. The owner Ervad Bahrāmjī Hīrājī gave the ms. to … Kāvaśjī (in return, he got a Vīdēvdād); later (in Saṃvat 1853) sold for 13 Rupees by the owner Mobed Śāpurjī Kāvaśjī Hīrā to Ervad Jamśedārū Dādābhāī Minocherjī Thoothājl Gōdrēj; then (Saṃvat 1871) in the possession of Edulji Manekji Ramji Dorabji Sāpurji Behmanji Pestonji Jivanji Kharshedji Jamshedji Nasserwanji Ratanji Rustomji Dorabji. On 3/3/1188 Y (1819) the Ms. was bought by Mobed Kaus Meherwān Bahman Kaus.

texts.text: Katrak gives the following information: "A couplet from a Monājāt of Dastur Darab Pahlon; a note in Gujrati, followed by a pedigree, in Zend, of the writer of this folio 1 (a); folio 1 (b), in different hand, gives the Nērang for Rōz 5, Māh 12, written in Zend and Pazend; next follows list of Contents, in Gujrati, folios 2–8; folios 9–10 have the 101 names of Hormazd, and a Monājat of Zarthosht Behram, in Persian, about the later sale of the Ms. from folio 11 begins the text proper, of the Ms. containing the Zend Alphabet, text and translation of Ashem, Yatha, Srosh Baj, and two Nyaeshes; other Nyāeshes, all the Gāhs, Patits, Afringāns, Afrins, Yashts, Nērangs, Nemaskārs, Bājs, Ashirwads &c, ending with the Bāj for cutting the Vanōt Darūn, on folio 371." "Prayers like Srosh Bāj, Ashem, Hōnvar, Khorshed and Maher Nyaēshes have Gujrati meanings" (Katrak)

manuscript.notes: At the beginning a table of contents, written by Anquetil. P3 consists of two unequal parts. Part I is a SkrY + Āfrīngān Dahmān + NyAtaš (which is given according to its celebration within the Long Liturgy in two parts)+ NyAban. The incipit given by Blochet (BLOCHET 1900, S. 15, gives for the „Nyāyishn de l’eau“ as Incipit: yazāi. āpəm. arəduuīm. sūrąm. anāhitąm.) shows that the text is in its Iranian recension (MayaYt). BLOCHET 1900, p. 15, No XVII, Suppl.persan29 = P3 says: „3° Nyāyishn du Feu. Commencement: Yasnemca vahmemca hubereitimca … fol. 131–132; 4° Le 68e Hâ du Yasna. Commencement: Vīspaēibyō s(t)astīm baraiti âtarsh … fol. 132–134.“ It is, however, the text vīspaēibiiō. sastīm. baraiti. ātarš., the beginning of Y 62.7, that part of the Ātaš Zōhr, that is separated from Y 62.6 by a Drôn in the Long Liturgy. The ms. on which is Anquetil's edition build on was translated by Anquetil, see Nouvelles ac. Fr. 8865 (Blochet LXXIII).

manuscript.notes: Dhabhar gives the following annotations: "(1) In the Srosh Bâj, the Ushahin–gâh is only given. (2) In the Khorshed Nyaish, all the gâhs are givem. (3) In the Mâh Nyaish, only the Aiwisruthrem gâh is given. (4) It is stated that 43 Atash Nyaishes should be recited during the day – 11 in the Havan, 9 in the Rapithwin, 7 in the Uzirin, 7 in the Aiwisruthrem an 9 in the Ushahin, (5) As the MS. is copied from that of Fredun Jiva, in the Patit–i Vadardegân, the name of Herbad Fredun is given. (6) In the Dhup–Nērang, recited for the living, the name should be thus taken: – Behdin Falân be rasâd. (7) In the Dibâche–i Afringan, the following names of the departed worthies are invoked among others: (1) Jamasp kai Pasin (and not Jamasp Habub, or Jamasp Hakim, as usual). (2) Firdusi Tusi. (3) Soban pandat. (4) Jaisal pandat. (5) Behdin Minocher B. Bahman. (6) Maneck B. Changa. (7) Dastur Khorshed D. Behram. (8) D. Asdin Erwad Kaka. (9) D. Mehrji E. Vachcha. (10) D. Shapur E. Hoshang. (11) D. Khorshed E. Kaikobad. (12) D. Burzor E. Kamdin. (13) D. Ardeshir E. Ramyar. (8) It is stated that the name of slave should be recited as Vahmân or Adar–cheher (f. 76) (9) In the recital of the Afringans, the Zoti should not recite Ahurahe Mazdâo raevatô kharenanghatô. (10) The Afrin of Hamkara of Haft–Amshâspand is called the Afrin of Behram Izad. (11) Two Afringans of Gahambar should be recited at the Gatha days. (12) Three Afrins– (1) of Behram Ized, (2) of Ardafravash and (3) of Pa–nâm–i Dâdâr should be recited after the Afringan ceremony. (13) Afringan Rapithwin should be recited twice during the year – (1) on day Khordad, month Farvardin, and (2) on day Marespand, month Meher."

texts.text: Description Asmussen (cf. description Geldner Prol., p. viii): "K 19 is less than half a complete codex of the Ḵorda Avesta. It is a modern manuscript of 318 folios, containing prayers; Nīāyeš 1–5; Gāh 1, 2–5; Yt. 1–5.50; bājes, patīt, Nērangs, and all the āfrīnagāns, āfrīns, gāhs, and namaskāras (Westergaard, 1846a, p. 114; Geldner, Prol., p. viii; Unvala, p. 145). The yašt fragment is de­scended from Pt 1, which was copied in 1625 from F 1, the archetype of all existing yašt manuscripts (Geldner, p. xliv; Hintze, passim). It also contains the Āfrīn ī payḡāmbar Zardušt (Westergaard, 1846a, pp. 300–01) and four Avestan fragments (pp. 331–32, frs. I–IV)."

manuscript.notes: 6697(Ml2) is an attempt to introduce a TXA in Iran. Cf. the printed Iranian XA from the time around 1900.
manuscript.ms_history: Geldner says that the ms. is "a collection of all the Avestâ texts and of many Avestâ fragments in Modern Persian script, put together for the most part from Iranian manuscripts". Panaino adds (according to Geldners statement, Prol., p. xlv, that the Ms. is "akin to J10") that "in many points it shows elements of Indian origin".

texts.text: Geldner gives the following information: "elegant modern codex, a collection of all the Avestâ texts and of many Avestâ fragments in Modern Persian script, put together for the most part from Iranian manuscripts." On p. xlv: "The only manuscript that might perhaps make any such claim is the great collective manuscript Ml2". "Yet certain Yashts, like the thirteenth and sixteenth, are wanting im Ml2, and the rest appear to have been compiled from multifarious sources. In cases where the Iranian and the Indian manuscripts stand opposed to each other, as in the fourteenth Yasht, Ml2 follows the Iranian. But the remainder points to Indian origin, to a manuscript near akin to J10."

texts.text: This ms. is called J58 by Dr. West in Grundriss der iran. Phil […]. It has three different colophons: (1) MS. written in AY 1108 by Ervad Jamshed Dastur Jamasp Asa Faredun; (2) MS. written in AY 1182 by Ervad Jamshed Ervad Edal Dastur Bahman Dastur Jamshed Jamasp Asa Faredun; (3) MS. written in AY 1189 by Ervad Edal Darab Jamshedji Jamaspji Asa Faredun." West refers to this Ms. (J58) in 1896–1904, in §25 on PahlTr NyAban; in §25 on PahlTr AGahambar (A3.3–13), ADahman, AFrawardigan (= A2.4); in §27 on PahlTr S 1+2; in §30 on Aog. Dhabhar gives the following description: "A MS. of mixed contents, including many portions of the Khorda–Avesta." According to the text information given by Dhabhar 1927 the ms. contains: AV, YAV, BajNanXwardan, BajGomK, NerKB (= StayišnDenih), SrB, NyXwar, NyMihr, NyMah, NyAban, NyAtaš, NamStayišn, PaAd, YtOhr, YtSrH, YtSr, ADahman, AGatha, AArdFrawahr, S 1, S 2, AfrinZ, AfrinBu, Afrin, PaymanagKadagXwaday

Bahman man neweštam barā–ye farzandān–e xod neweštam. It follows two lines of poetry (from V 3.32–33): yat̰. yauuō. pouruš. bauuāt̰. aδa. mąθrən. taδa. mairiiāt̰. On p. 2 the bool is called Xwardag Abestāg bā Zand. Then the text says that it is written "from the Asemwohū to the beginning/end of the Drōn (drōn sar)". Thus, it seems, that the original ms. contained a Drōn (cf. T12 and related mss.). texts.text: Dahbhar gives the following information: "This is a MS. very carefully written by Dastur Edalji Darabji Sanjana in A.Y. 1169. It contains a very good Persian translation of nearly the whole Khorda–Avesta. It is expressly mentioned that the Bahram Yasht was translated into Persian by Mobed Darab Rustam Sanjana. I have found that a goodly number of Persian glosses scattered in the long or short prayers in this MS. have been translated verbatim, often in correct Pahlavi, by Dastur Edalji Darabji Sanjana and incorporated in his Khorda–Avesta MS. D (...) described above ... As stated above, the often ungrammatical and modern Pahlavi versions, e.g., of some of the longer pieces of prayers such as Patit Aderbad (longer Pahlavi version), Ardibehesht Yasht, the Behram Yasht, etc., seem to have been done into that language from Persian version, such as the one found in this MS."

texts.text: "This volume […] comprises a large selection of Zoroastrian prayers, doxologies, and other religious formulae, written for the most part in the proper Avestic character, with Persian translations and running commentaries. It begins with the Ashem vôhû and Yathâ ahû vairyô formulae, followed by the Kushtî–nîrang, the Wâj–i–ṭaʿám khurdan (grace before meat), andc. (ff. 1–16a) Then follow the Khurshîd–niyáyish, Mihr–niyáyish, Máh–niyáyish, andc. (ff. 16a–48b); the Hávan–gáh, Rapithvan–gáh, andc. (ff. 48b–68b); the Húrmazd Yasht, Urdî–bihisht Yasht, andc. (ff. 69a–114b); various Patêts, Nîrangs, Áfrínagáns, including the Íránî–Patêt (ff. 200a–217a), in 20 cluases called karda, the Marriage Service (ff. 217a–224a: nekāḥ pahlawī bā maʿnī), the Khud–Patêt (ff. 224a–233a), in 31 clauses; and finally the Sîrúza–i–khurd (ff. 330b–342a), an account of the 21 Nasks (ff. 342a–344b), and a few short prayers in 'Pázend,' with translation and explanations in Persian." (denison Ross/Brown 1902, p. 136) On fol. 351b the text on the number of YAV to be recited (breaks off abruptly).

Rewāyat in Pāzand (fol. 28 r): 1) Sur les vêtements qu‘il faut revêtir pour célébrer les Yashts (fol. 28 v); 2) Cérémonies à observer aux funérailles d’un enfant mort à douze ans (29 r); 3) Un homme aveugle ne peut être herbed (fol. 29 r); 4) Un homme de rien, mardī nést, peut être herbed (fol. 29 r); 5) Un homme qui a les oreilles percées également, mais il ne peut le barashnom; autres conditions pour étre herbed (fol. 29 v); 6) Héritages (fol. 29 v); 7) Adoption par un homme qui n’a pas d’enfants; il faut sevrer les garçons à dix–sept mois, les filles à quinze; pollutions nocturnes (fol. 30 r); 8) Funérailles d’une femme morte enceinte; ce que l’on doit faire d’un animal domestique qui a mange de la nasu; ce que l’on doit faire après l’accouchement (foll. 30 v – 31 r); 9) Célébration du dâroûn; Dakhmas (fol. 32 r); 10) Le dâroûn ne doit pas être célébré devant un étranger (anér) ou une femme dashtân; sur le barashnom (fol. 32 v); 11) Sur le Kosti; L’homme qui meurt sans que l‘on sache son nom; sur l’eau qui coule dans un dakhma (fol. 33 v); 12) Sur le Penom (panâm); Les habits que doit porter la femme dashtân; commerce aves les femmes; prières que l’on doit reciter (foll. 33 v – 34 r); 13) Sur le barsôm (fol. 34 v); 14) Enfant de hui tans qui commet un tanafur (tanāvír) (fol. 35 r); 15) Sur la celebration des Yasht et Stāyishn (fol. 36 r); 16) Le Barashnom; Adoption par un homme qui n’a pas d’enfants, cérémonie du dāroūn (fol. 36 v); 17) Choses à faire quand on se brûle; femme dashtân (fol. 37 r); 18) Nasu qui trouve sur un arbre et qui tombe sur un homme (foll. 38 v – 40 r); 19) Sur le Barashnom (fol. 40 v); 20) Office du dāroūn (fol. 41 r); 21) Jeune homme de quinze ans qui n’a fait ni le nô–zoûd ni le gītī–khirīd; commerce avec une femme; sur le dāroūn (fol. 41 v); 22) Enfant de douze ans qui n’a pas de kostī (fol. 42 r); 23) Sur la navigation; sur le Barashnom (fol. 43 r); 24) Femme qui entreprend un voyage sur mer; femme enceinte qui meurt; sur le Barashnom (fol. 46 r); 25) Dessins schématiques representant le plan du Barashnom Gāh (foll. 46 v – 47 r); 26) Décision tirée de l’Avesta sur le nām zāt d’une fille de neu fans (fol. 47 v); 27) Idem, suivant laquelle il ne faut pas tuer un animal domestique (gôspent) avant qu’il ait attaint l’âge d’un an; deux herbeds doivent reciter l’Afergān Gāhānbār (fol. 48 v); 28) Le Nōzoûd; ce qu’il faut faire pour installer le feu dans l‘Adarān; nombre de Yathâ Ahû Vairyô qu’il y a dans le Khurshīt Nyāyishn, le Māh Nyāyishn, le Srōsh Yasht, le Yasht d’Ardibehesht; manuscript.ms_history: 1821/26 in the posession of a Persian Zoroastrian. 1859 given to the library of St. Petersburg. Origin: "Wasz zunächst die herkunft der handschrift betrift, so stamt die ganze von dem ehemaligen ruszischen gesanten am Teheraner hofe, fürsten Dolgoruky, zusammen gebrachte samlung ausz Persien ... Auszerdem sprechen noch zwei umstände für den persischen ursprung des codex: und zwar zuerst die beiden oben XIIIc angeführten notizen von besuchen fürstlicher personden in Yezd a.h. 1171 und 1194 ...; als zweiter grund aber eine orthographische besonderheit, auf welche schon Anquetil hin gewisen hat." (ū = Kermān ī) (Salemann, p. 500–501). The visitors were Kerīm Xān in 1171/1757 and Alī Taqī Xān Sādiq Xān in 1194/1780. However, the dates are written on sheets that were later added.

manuscript.notes: Incomplete at the end. Hampel 1974, p. xvi–xvii, gives the following description: "Die handschrift selbst liegt in einem Umschlag in der Königlichen Bibliothek zu Kopenhagen. Die Blätter der Handschrift sind gut erhalten, und die schwarzen Schriftzeichen auf dem hellgrauen Papier sind deutich lesbar. Eine Ausnahme bilden drei Blätter, die durch Lakunen teilweise unleserlich geworden sind. Die Papierränder sind handgerissen. Die Blätter haben ein Format von 14 cm mal 46 cm. Dieses Format wurde in der Mitte quer gefaltet. Die entstandenen vie Seiten (im Format 14 mal 23) sind dann mit zumeist fünfzehn Schriftzeilen beschrieben worden. Diese vier Seiten eines Doppelblattes enthalten aber keinen fortlaufenden Text. Da mehrere Blätter zusammengelegt und gefaltet wurden und dann beschrieben sind, steht der fortlaufende Text auf verschiedenen Blättern. Dazu kommt, daß viele Doppelblätter am Falz gerissen sind. So liegen die Blätter nicht in der Reihenfolge und mußten erst dem Inhalt nach geordnet werden. Das ganze Doppelblatt hat eine Guzarātī–Numerierung an der rechten oberen Ecke. Die Handschrift besteht aus 66 Seiten – ursprünglich muß sie jedoch umfangreicher gewesen sein, denn das letzte Gebet bricht mitten im Text ab."

manuscript.notes: Asmussen: "K 25 is an undated Pahlavi codex of 135 folios, containing various texts, primarily from Ḵorda Avesta but also excerpts in Pazand; according to Barr, it was probably copied after 1600. It has not yet been published in its entirety. The texts include Ṣefat–e Sīrōza; Frahang ī pahlawīg (fols. 49r–73v), with in­terlinear Pazand transcription, used by H. F. J. Junker only at the proof stage of his edition, which thus includes only a selection of its readings, but fully collated by H. S. Nyberg (pp. xi–xii); the Avestan and Pahlavi alphabets (fol. 74r) in the order of the Arabic alphabet (Nyberg, p. 33); Izeshne rafitwan; Āfrīnagān rapiθwin; Āfrīn ī payḡāmbar Zardušt (Westergaard, 1846a, pp. 300–01); Sīrōza and Ḵorda Avesta; and Avestan fragments (Westergaard, 1846a, p. 333, frs. V, VII)." K25 contains some of those Xšnūmans which are typically found in Iranian XA or Drōn mss.; it is especially worth notice that K25 like K38 includes only G1 which appears together with Xšnūman texts. The FPahl was published in: Barr, K. 1944: Selections from Codices K7 and K25 (Vispered and Frahang i Pahlavīk) and Tracings of the Avesta Codex K1. Codices Avestici et Pahlavici Bibliothecae Universitatis Hafniensis, vol. XII. Kopenhagen.

manuscript.notes: Sammelhandschrift, 3 parts. Katrak gives the information „The last folio contains the Pahlavi Nērang of Avesta Darun Faravaharam Yasht; after the formula ‘Fravarānē …….vidhvāo mraotū,’ occurs in Pahlavi thus: “Praise andc of Got; Avesta of Faravahārām (i.e. Farvardin) yasht is written; may it be preserved; Beginning of the First Kardeh.” Here the 31 Kardehs of the Iranian Farvardin Yasht are not given; but last line of the text is: ‘Firōz bād ……ashemvohū one to be recited’. followed by the colophon of Jamasp Hakim, along with his predecessor’s.”
